ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ACTIVITIES TO CLOSE RELIGIOUS AND RACIAL DIVIDE
(Monitoring progress)


    1. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Acting Minister for Community Development and Sports in view of the importance of closing the religious and racial divide with activities such as the Inter-Racial Confidence Circles and more diverse ethnic representation at grassroots activities and youth groups, (a) whether his Ministry is monitoring the progress of these activities and (b) what are the criteria used to monitor them.

    The Acting Minister for Community Development and Sports (Assoc. Prof. Yaacob Ibrahim): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am happy to note that the Government, schools, grassroots, and non-governmental organisations have taken pro-active steps to build bridges and promote understanding between the various communities. For example, MOE has formed a committee to promote broader and deeper inter-racial mixing and understanding in schools. The Muslim Religious Council (MUIS) will foster greater understanding about Islam and the Muslim community through goodwill visits, dialogues and activities with grassroots and other organisations. A strong network of informal links between the respective agencies and community organisations enable efforts to be coordinated and experiences to be shared.

    With the establishment of the Inter-Racial Confidence Circles (IRCCs) and

Column: 939

the Harmony Circles, these would be important vehicles to catalyse action on the ground and to contribute to the building of trust and confidence. To guide and coordinate these efforts, we have set up a National Steering Committee for the IRCCs. The National Steering Committee can play a useful role to monitor and integrate the efforts of various organisations, both through the formal committee process as well as dialogues and sharing.

    Mrs Yu-Foo asked about the criteria for monitoring progress in fostering racial harmony. The building of trust and confidence among the different races and religions is a continuous process. Organisations such as the People's Association do monitor the participation rate of various communities. This serves as a broad indicator of our integration efforts. However, what is important in fostering racial harmony is not to set rigid success indicators. Rather, we must see constant conscientious efforts to strengthen our social cohesion.

SEXUAL ABUSE CASES INVOLVING WOMEN AND CHILDREN


    2. Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Acting Minister for Community Development and Sports (a) what is the trend of sexual abuse cases involving women and children and (b) what measures are being put in place to deal with and deter such abuse.

    Assoc. Prof. Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, the number of sexual abuse cases involving children and women in Singapore has been constant for the past 3 years. There were about 400 cases investigated by the Police per year for the last two years for girls below 16 years. There was a slight decrease among those aged 16 years and above from 805 in 2000 to 711 in 2001.

    Victims are given professional help and support to minimise the traumatic impact so that they are able to lead meaningful lives. In the event that the victim and perpetrator are staying in the same household, the victim will be removed to

Column: 940

a place of safety. The National Standards on the Protection of Children launched by my Ministry in February this year ensures that the management of child protection, including sexual abuse, will be prompt and handled with the child's interest as a priority. The courts also mete out deterrent sentences on perpetrators of child abuse.

    At the preventive level, key professionals, including medical social workers, doctors, police, social workers, pre-school and child care teachers are trained to identify symptoms of abuse and reach out to victims early. Furthermore, the Police preventive measures of sexual abuse run at two levels. For the general population, Police conducts school talks for students on the prevention of sexual abuse, for example, how not to fall prey to molesters and avert sex predators on the prowl in the Internet Relay Chat. Students are also advised on what to do if one is a victim. A total of 243 such school talks were conducted in 2001. In addition, Police disseminates advice on the prevention of sexual abuse through brochures and posters displayed at service counters of police establishments, schools and family service centres. 'Crimewatch' is another medium which Police uses to educate the public on such crime prevention messages.

    For specific target groups, the Criminal Investigations Department (CID) conducts training sessions on the law governing various types of sexual offences and on police procedures to deal with them. These target groups include MOE school teachers and members of the Parents Advisory Group for the Internet (PAGi). As these individuals have regular contact with children and adolescents in their respective vocations, the training provided by CID creates awareness on how to prevent, detect and report instances of sexual abuse. With greater awareness, caregivers and victims alike can take necessary steps to prevent sexual abuse.

    Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong): Sir, can the Minister give us a profile of the families at risk, ie, the families that are involved in such cases?

Column: 941



    Assoc. Prof. Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, from the data we have, we see no significant trend in terms of the types of families which are involved. Some cases do not get reported.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Deferment and loan restructuring of mortgage instalments)


    3. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the number of applications received by the Housing and Development Board for deferment and loan restructuring of the mortgage loan instalment payment since 2001 by size of flats; (b) how have the numbers changed over time; and (c) the number of such outstanding cases also by size of flats.

    The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB's existing financial assistance measures for mortgagors in financial hardship include: (i) conversion to a reduced repayment scheme, under which a mortgagor can pay 75% of his normal instalment for a period of five years, (ii) deferment of instalments for a period of 6 months, and (iii) extension of loan repayment period.

    Between January 2001 and March 2002, HDB received 18,200 applications for assistance under these measures. Of these, only 14 were rejected because these households were not in genuine financial hardship. 3, 4 and 5-room mortgagors accounted for 29%, 41% and 29% respectively of the successful applications during this period.

    14,200 of these new cases were assisted in 2001. This compares against 15,000 new cases in 1999, and 10,000 new cases in 2000.

    As at 31st March 2002, 15,300 of the cases assisted since January 2001 remained active. The flat type distribution among these cases is similar to that of new cases assisted during this period, ie,

Column: 942

with 3, 4 and 5-room mortgagors accounting for 28%, 42% and 30% respectively of these cases.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): It was reported in the Business Times yesterday that there were 19,400 mortgage loan deferment cases. I would like to ask the Minister of State if the 19,400 cases refer to the arrears and if some of the loan deferment cases are also included in the 19,400 cases.

    The other question I would like to ask the Minister is whether there are many applications for extension of the deferment cases after the expiry of the initial six months allowed. And if so, how would such deferment be given or extended?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Sir, the report carried in the Business Times yesterday referred to cases which were in arrears in excess of three months. These are quite distinct figures from the figures which I have given, which cover cases which have approached the Board for assistance.

    The key point here is that there is actually no need to go into arrears. The take-home message is that if people were to approach the Housing and Development Board early enough when they anticipate that their financial circumstances have changed, there are more than adequate measures in place to assist these people.

    The Member's next question was on people who still continue to experience financial hardship beyond the six months. There are measures which are in place. We can reschedule the loans. We can add more names to the co-owners of the flat and take any other measures which were not utilised earlier to assist these people as well.

    Mr Ahmad Khalis Bin Abdul Ghani (Hong Kah): Sir, would the Minister of State kindly reconsider relaxing the rules regarding the requirement that a person who wants to resell his flat must own the flat for five years, in the case of a new flat, or three years, in the case of a resale flat, in order to downgrade, in the event that

Column: 943

there is genuine hardship on the part of the owner?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: In cases of severe financial hardship, the HDB does, on a case-by-case basis, allow families in these circumstances to sell their flats before the minimum occupation period has expired.

PROMOTING AND NURTURING CREATIVITY IN SCHOOL


    4. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Education (a) what proportion of the time in the curriculum and the student's time in school is devoted to promoting and nurturing creativity and (b) will his Ministry be conducting a study to evaluate the success of this effort and, if so, what kind of performance indicator will be used.

    The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the approach adopted to nurturing creativity in students is not through teaching specific modules on creativity or teaching it as a separate subject. Our approach to promoting and nurturing creativity is through infusion across the curriculum and through project work, teaching methodologies and the assessment system itself. Lessons in any subject that arouse a lively curiosity in students foster creative thinking and imagination. Our Science and Mathematics programmes, for example, help students to develop this curiosity by encouraging enquiry and getting them to provide their own solutions to problems. Activities with open-ended investigations such as the Maths trail, which is an activity conducted outside the classroom, require students to use varied strategies to solve problems or seek alternative solutions to problems. Teachers are also conducting activities to make science an experiential learning for students, especially at the primary school level. One activity in primary schools, for example, involves having the students learn more about

Column: 944

themselves through taking their finger prints. In addition, an activity like project work, which is now required from primary school upwards, provides opportunities for students to look at events with fresh perspectives, to come up with their own responses to problems and issues and to investigate, explore and try out new ways of doing things. Project work also encourages students to break away from the compartmentalisation of the different subject disciplines and explore the inter-relationships between different areas of knowledge when applied to real life situations.

    There is no single indicator that can give a reliable measure of the success of our efforts to promote creativity. However, we are changing the assessment system in the individual subjects so that problem solving, inference skills and creative thinking are given greater emphasis in the assessments. For example, in English Literature, the introduction of unseen material - material that the students have not previously seen - in the assessment system develops students' quality of thinking and their application of principles of critical reading to the unseen passages of prose or poetry. Such critical appreciation enables students to demonstrate their individual insights and original thinking beyond text knowledge. In history, questions based on original sources - source-based questions, as they call it - have been introduced to assess students' thinking and analytical skills in the interpretation and evaluation of issues in their original historical context. And in the sciences, we are introducing a new way of assessing practical skills over a period of time instead of a one-off practical examination, to promote a broader understanding of scientific process skills associated with scientific inquiry and problem-solving.

    Project work will be required for entry to university in future, and this is project work that is in most cases interdisciplinary. How our students respond to these new assessment items will give some indication of how successful we have been. Beyond the schools, in our higher and further education institutions,

Column: 945

curriculum and teaching methodology has also been changed to encourage more creativity. It will take a number of years for the effects of these changes to be fully felt.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): May I know if Confucianism, as a subject, or as part of the civic lessons, or in any way, still taught in our schools?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Sir, I do not have the particulars of the syllabus. I do not know whether Confucianism in some form is still part of the curriculum. But I would not be surprised if all the Asian traditions are still present in our curriculum in one form or another.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): The Minister of State, in his answer, says that project work will be introduced. My concern is whether the teachers are adequately prepared to guide the students in the project work because it is a fairly new component being introduced. My experience shows that sometimes students are a bit confused as to what are the requirements and the guidelines. So my question is whether teachers are sufficiently prepared beforehand and what are the preparations that teachers have gone through.

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Sir, our project work at junior colleges - I think this is what the Member is referring to - is currently at the pilot stage. It is still early days. We have put considerable effort into preparing the teachers. So far, the pilot stage has been proceeding well. Teachers are learning as they go along. When we are confident that the junior colleges are able to implement project work to realise the intent of the scheme, we will be implementing it as a requirement for university admission.

    Dr Warren Lee (Sembawang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have received some feedback about this project work that, especially in primary schools, it ends up that the parents actually end up doing the project work on behalf of their children. While I can see that good things are being said about having project work in later years in school, I wonder whether the

Column: 946

Ministry has some measures to put in place to make sure that the project work in primary school really comes from the students, and not from the parents.

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Sir, I would not be surprised if what the Member described is not at least partially true. That is a social rather than an educational phenomenon. Project work at primary school, however, does not count in the overall assessment system. At the junior colleges where it is going to count, the safeguards are in place. The project work is done by a team of students in the school under the supervision of a teacher.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: I would like to ask the Minister of State, in the case of project work in primary school, if the Ministry has studied whether enough time is allocated within school hours to do the project work because, although it is a social rather than an educational issue, the temptation would be that when the project work is brought home, the parents will come into the picture.

    Another question relates to Mathematics problem sums in primary school. My understanding is that, presently, the teachers require the students to tackle the problem in a certain manner. They have to have models, and it seems that if the students can get the answer without the models, marks are deducted. I would like to ask the Minister if this could be studied carefully, because if you want to foster creativity, then it should be a matter of getting the right answers based on the child's manner of thinking and rationalising, instead of a fixed mode of solving the problem.

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Sir, on the first question of whether adequate time is provided during school hours for project work to be done, I do not think we would want to have a situation where all project work is done during school hours in the primary schools. It would crowd out something else. We have a heavy enough curriculum. We want project work to enrich the curriculum. If we try and do it all during the same number of hours, then something else has to fall off, and that is

Column: 947

typically something else that is valuable. I see nothing wrong in project work at the primary school level being done partially outside school hours, at home. I do not think we should worry too much if the mother or the father is providing some guidance. It is the spirit of project work that is important at the end of the day and teachers will have to assess whether the child is actually capable of the project work he does.

    On the second question of Mathematics problems, I take the Member's point that we would like Mathematics to be taught and assessed in primary schools, or at any level, in a way which recognises that there are different methods to the right answer. This is not a matter of the curriculum or the syllabus as much as teaching methodologies in individual schools. I have come across anecdotal examples that are raised where there might have been too rigid treatment of a particular problem and teachers are not sufficiently forgiving of different methods. These are problems on the ground that are to be expected. On the whole, I do not think we have a severe problem. Our teachers, by and large, try to encourage children to understand the principles behind the Mathematics problem. But I would not deny that there are instances that we come across.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Would the Minister elaborate how would project work be assessed as an admission criterion for going to university in the future? Is it done by the university concerned, the faculty concerned, or would there be a central examination board in assessing this project work?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Details of the assessment methodology are being finalised. Assessment is not done by the universities. It will be done within the existing framework of our 'A' level examinations, the Singapore-Cambridge 'A' level examinations. It is a rigorous procedure, with care taken to ensure that there is no bias in the assessment of

Column: 948

students' projects. So I do not think we need to worry about the integrity of the process.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may ask the Minister whether the emphasis on project work has helped to reduce the emphasis on grade, if any?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: If the Member's question is on how project work is reducing the emphasis on written examinations, if that is what he meant, I think it will. Project work looks at process skills, and is a very useful supplement to the existing system of written examinations. Like I said, it is early days. We are still improving the process but the Ministry of Education does feel that the project work is going to be an integral component of assessment system in the future.

    Dr Ong Seh Hong (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to seek the Minister of State's clarification. Since project work is a supplement or additional to the existing curriculum, will it not be an additional stress on the students now that, as he stated correctly, the students already have quite a heavy curriculum? The other issue is: what are the steps that the Ministry will take to make sure that project work will not become another examination where the students will prepare for it and that they have to get a good grade to get into the university?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: On the Member's first question, Sir, it is not the intent that project work should create a new source of stress, nor do we think that that will be the outcome. We are monitoring this carefully at the pilot stage. We want to make sure that project work is not an add-on to the existing assessment system, but is really a complement to the existing assessment system. Taken together, we want to make sure that the overall workload of junior college students does not increase. I think the Member's fear is a natural one. It is not without basis because we know how things work out in practice quite easily. So we have to watch this carefully and make

Column: 949

sure that work pressure does not go up and stress levels do not go up unnecessarily. It is not the intention that they should. What is the Member's next question?

    Dr Ong Seh Hong: What are the steps that the Ministry will take to make sure that it will not deteriorate into just another form of examination?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: I have no doubt that our junior college students will take any form of assessment seriously. I do not think we can help that. But if we did not assess this and we did not attempt to measure performance, then given the same culture of taking seriously only what is assessed, people will simply not pay too much attention to project work and will not pay too much attention to the process skills that we are trying to cultivate. So we have to assess this and that provides the incentive for students to take project work and process skills seriously.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, the Minister of State's answer is that we know how the ground works here on education. How sure is he that the project work will not become an added pressure on the students which is contrary to the objective of the Ministry of Education?

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, the Minister of State's answer is that we know how the ground works here on education. How sure is he that that the project work will not become an added pressure on the students which is contrary to the objective of the Ministry of Education?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Sir, to take a couple of steps back, why have we introduced project work? We introduced it because we are trying to reduce the extent of the emphasis on written examinations. And I am sure everyone agrees that that is a good thing. How we go about putting it into practice is important. We are going to put it to practice in a sensible fashion where we are going to accord it the weight it deserves, not too much weight. We are going to make sure that how teachers guide students, how students actually go about the process, is going to reflect the spirit of this whole exercise which is not just to accumulate marks as easily as possible, but to really use the exercises as an opportunity to gain new skills of enquiry and experimentation. There is no guarantee that any form of assessment is not going to lead to stress or pressure.

Column: 950

There can be no guarantee. But it is not our intention that it be the case.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, from what I gather from the answer given to my last question, the schools are still teaching Confucianism. If Confucianism is taught in a significant way, may I ask the Minister whether it will not be in conflict with the attempt of schools trying to nurture creativity?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Sir, as I mentioned earlier, I really do not have the specifics with me on the details of what elements of Confucianism are in our curriculum. But I would not be surprised if Confucianism, like the other Asian traditions, remains in our curriculum and for good reason. There is Confucianism and there is Confucianism. It is a broad subject. You are able to pick elements out of it which you feel are important for children to understand, appreciate and imbibe and which remain as relevant to our future as they have been in our past. I do not have the specifics on exactly which elements remain in our curriculum. But I do not think the Ministry needs to be defensive about having elements of a very important Asian philosophy and tradition remaining in our curriculum.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may ask the Minister how much time is given for the project work and project presentation, whether it is done during class time or outside class time, and whether a reduction in class size will actually help to give the students more time for more project work presentation?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Project work, when it is fully implemented, will be part of the curriculum. In other words, it is not an enrichment activity taken entirely outside of regular hours.

    As to class size, project work is not conducted in a full-class fashion. It is conducted by teams of students in small groups, as has to be the case, given the nature of project work. It is an applied exercise. So it is conducted in small groups.

Column: 951



    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State whether he agrees with the hon. Member for Potong Pasir that teaching of Asian cultures and traditions such as Confucianism in schools will stifle creativity.

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Sir, this subject is worth several dissertations. I am not capable of even half a dissertation on the subject but, from the very little I know about the way we have sought to incorporate these traditions or Asian cultures in our curriculum, I have no reason to think that it will stifle creativity. There has to be a certain tension between retaining ballast and the desire to explore something new, and the desire to explore something new is given strength by how much ballast we have. If it is all exploring the new, the future or the next big thing, I think we can easily fall flat. We have to retain a certain core of what represents eternal truths, eternal principles, in order to explore what is new. So I do not think we need feel defensive about learning about tradition, understanding it well, understanding what is weak in our past traditions as well as understanding what is strong.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Sir, can I clarify that this new smaller class size, as what the Minister said, will actually help to improve the current emphasis on project work?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: To clarify, Sir, I was not talking about smaller class size as such, but I was talking about the way in which project work is implemented, that project work is not a whole class activity but is an activity pursued by groups of students within any particular class.

STUDENTS FACING PSYCHOLOGICAL PRESSURE
(Counselling/support services)


    5. Mr Gan Kim Yong asked the Minister for Education what counselling or support services are available in the schools or in his Ministry to help students in the primary and secondary schools cope with the psychological pressure they may face from time to time.

    Let us just look at the left side of the chart. There are two examples. On the left, there are two scenarios: one, where the retailer is GST-registered; one where the retailer is not registered. The retailer paid the manufacturer $200 for the set. His mark-up was $100. The manufacturer paid the parts supplier $100 for the set. The manufacturer's mark-up was $100. Now, how much GST was paid? The parts supplier paid $5 of GST to IRAS, because

Column: 1069

his price was $100, he paid $5. The manufacturer paid $10 of GST to IRAS because his price was $200, 5% of $200 is $10. But because the manufacturer paid the supplier $100 plus $5, so he claimed from IRAS a refund of $5, so the manufacturer paid $5. The retailer pays $15 of GST, which he collected from a consumer, to IRAS. But the retailer had already paid $10 of the GST to the manufacturer, so he gets a refund of $10 from IRAS. So the total amount of GST collected by IRAS on the television set, from the start of the process, when it was components all the way to the end when it was delivered to the consumer is $5 plus $5 plus $5, it is $15. These are all very specialised skills. You need the touch, you need the experience. The Government is not in it. But even if you had venture capital in Singapore, not everybody will

Column: 1076

get funding. In Silicon Valley, only one project out of 20 gets funding. That is why the projects which do get funding are promising, because there is ruthless competition, survival of the fittest. Only the best get funding, and even then after being funded, many of them fail. So if we try to short-circuit this Darwinian process and say I will give more generously, let us hope a hundred flowers will bloom. Are you sure? You may have thrown your money away and planted weeds. So you have to be very careful talking about venture capital.

    We also have to be very careful in favouring small and medium enterprises for Government contracts. It sounds good, it is very popular, but it can result in inefficiency. If you want to cut back on Government spending, this is not the way to do it. Tender, best bidder, best qualified to provide the service, most efficient, best quality, wins contract, he supplies the Government. Countries which have tried to favour SMEs have found that it leads to great inefficiencies. The Japanese have tried, the Germans have tried, other countries have tried. It is better to have schemes to help the SMEs get started, help them improve their productivity and capability, and then they have to compete and hold their own. And if they cannot hold their own, if they cannot compete, then the market has to sort it out. We hope that many will succeed, but we cannot expect none of them to fail.

    But the future of our economy does not just depend on the SMEs. We will rationalise the traditional SMEs. We will promote new SMEs to start, but we also need new growth areas. We also need MNCs. We also need major companies, to create new jobs to replace jobs which are being lost.

    The GLCs are part of the solution, not part of the problem. Many MPs have asked whether the GLCs have been stifling entrepreneurship, crowding out local players. Dr Amy Khor asked this. Mr Inderjit Singh says, why not the Government simply divest GLCs. I would if it were so simple. It is not the mission of Temasek or of the GLCs to crowd out small and

Column: 1077

medium enterprises. We gain nothing. Our job, as I explained, is to have companies which are strategic to our economy, or which have regional potential to grow and become international players. Other companies not relevant, Temasek will progressively divest when the conditions are right.

    At the borders, some overlap is inevitable, and it is especially troublesome with statutory board companies in the process of being completely privatised but not quite there yet. Members mentioned PWD Consultants. There are a couple of others which are in the process of being privatised, where moratoriums were given, and there is some feeling that this is not quite at an arm's length relationship yet. But our policy is that we should maintain a strictly arm's length relationship between such companies and their statutory boards. In fact, we should cut the umbilical cord as soon as possible and separate them, either divest them off completely or they should go and be put under Temasek or under some other Government agency. So it is not directly held by the statutory board and there is no incentive for transfer pricing or some non-transparent arrangements, which will cause problems and inefficiencies and difficulties to the private sector.

    We do not post senior civil servants to the GLCs. Dr Wang Kai Yuen says we do it for talent development. I think he was being polite. We do not do it. Mr Inderjit Singh also said we have senior civil servants posted there for career rotations. We do not do that. The GLCs have their own staff. They recruit their own. They recruit on the market. They find the best they can get and if the people are not good enough, they have to go. They are run commercially by their managements. They are not run by the civil servants. The civil servants have enough to do without going into other business.

    Mr Inderjit Singh cited vigorously problems of GLCs stifling entrepreneurship, crowding out local companies through unfair practices, or dominating and predatory practices, compelling foreign companies to work with GLCs. It sounded

Column: 1078

awful but, unfortunately, he did not give any particulars. So I would encourage him, if he has any specific information of actual cases, to let me have the evidence. I will expunge his name and pass the evidence along, investigate it personally and put it right.

    Let us be quite honest and adult about this. Competition is a fact of life. Even if we privatised the GLCs and the Government washed its hands altogether and found a good private owner to own and manage it, they would still be formidable competitors to the SMEs. They are well organised. They are bigger. They have the depth of management expertise and they are able to deliver a service or a good and get the job done. So whoever owns the GLCs, the SMEs are still going to face severe competition. The broader question for us, as a Government, is not whether the GLCs win or the SMEs win. The question is: are the GLCs competing fairly? Is the result that the most efficient company succeeds and delivers the best service for the economy and the best value-added and the highest productivity? Or is the GLC winning because there is some inside track, some unfair advantage, some improper information which they are taking advantage of and therefore clobbering the SMEs and the private companies? If there is, they are harming the economy and we must put a stop to it. If there is not, and they are competing fairly, I say a certain amount of robust competition is unavoidable. But it is not their job to go and look for small business. Their mission is what we have defined for Temasek and Temasek will have a charter which will be published soon.

    Next, CPF. Mr Inderjit Singh argued for lower contribution rates in the longer term. It was one of his wish-list items. Mr Othman Haron voiced concern that workers might face difficulties with their housing commitments if CPF contribution rates were lowered. I agree with Mr Othman Haron. I also agree with Mr Matthias Yao that the fundamental objectives of the CPF should not be diluted. He put it in a very neat and succinct form yesterday and I would like to quote him in toto because this is something which

Column: 1079

bears repeating and which I think Singaporeans need to be reassured of. We are not going to muck around with the CPF. CPF, as Matthias said, is for retirement, housing and healthcare. Everything else should be secondary and we should not use CPF as a macro-economic tool to alter the money supply or disposable income. Workers should be receptive to changes that might be necessary if they are not to be priced out of a job. So it may be necessary for us to adjust the CPF scheme but any changes made will be phased in carefully and we will give as much time as possible for Singaporeans to adjust. And I may add what I have said before, that we promise to restore it to 40%, and that stands. It may take us some time, but we will do it.

    Now, I would like to address a few points briefly. On medical benefits, Members made their sentiments unambiguously known, many lady MPs and a few men too. I should explain that under the new Medisave-cum-Subsidised Outpatient (MSO) scheme, in fact, we have essentially equalised, because whether you are a male or a female officer, what you get is one extra percent on your CPF in Medisave. You have $350 worth of outpatient allowance, which you can use for yourself. At the end of the year, if you do not use it, it goes into your Medisave. The men can use it for their children, the women, cannot. But at the end of the year it goes to the women anyway. So essentially, it is the same. For the older schemes, we have not changed it yet. There is still a distinction. I am sure we will discuss that in the Committee of Supply.

    On HDB parking charges, this point will be dealt with amply, I am quite confident, when the Committee of Supply discusses Mr Mah Bow Tan's budget for MND.

    On older workers, this is a separate problem, not addressed by our tax restructuring package. The problem is not funding. It is not availability of training programmes. It is a matching of workers with vacancies. We have the People-for-Jobs Traineeship Programme. It has

Column: 1080

trained about 2,000 unemployed workers and executives. Some workers are still not taking advantage of it. But let us pursue these programmes. Let us try and get them to work before introducing or thinking about more permanent measures, like subsidies and rebates.

    Finally, Dr Amy Khor and Mr Yeo Guat Kwang asked the Government to take care of Singaporeans who are struggling to cope with economic restructuring. Yes, I fully agree that this is indeed the basis for the generous offset package for the GST, and we have given special attention to make sure that the lower-income group will not be worse off.

    Sir, I think I have addressed all the major points raised. I have not fulfilled all the wish lists, but perhaps it is just as well. Because, for example, Mr Inderjit Singh asked for a 30% reduction in the price of all properties. I would suggest to him to consider this very carefully because it means that all his residents, who are also my residents, will suffer a 30% reduction in their property values, and that is not likely to be considered. And if we halve the petrol tax and ERP charges, foreign workers' levy and property tax, what he has not told you is that Santa Claus comes and the bill arrives the next day, and the Government's bill to do all this may be a much higher GST than 5%, maybe 6%, maybe 7%, maybe 10%. So before you sign on, better find out what the deal is.

    This is not a complete response to the challenges which face us, as Dr Amy Khor and others have pointed out. Dr Amy Khor said it is just one piece of a jigsaw puzzle. She is right. The ERC's recommendations are yet to come. We are working on it. There are sectoral policies to deal with financial services, manufacturing, other services to deal with SMEs, to deal with helping the older workers cope. We have a human resources package working on it. We have to deal with the CPF and wage issues. It will take time to work these out and implement them. But the first step is fiscal reform, and this we have done.

    Our competitive pressures are increasing, but we can rise up to the challenge,

Column: 1081

and I think we have strong reasons to believe that we will succeed. Our political and social stability, our market access to major economies, our pro-market Government policies, our ability to adapt to changes quickly - these are traditional strengths - we have repeatedly cited them, but they remain valid and they will help to see us through the next period.

    We are still competitive. We are acting now, not because we already have a problem, but because we see the problem ahead. World-class companies still find Singapore a good place for investments. We have had a big project between AMD and UMC to build a 15th wafer fab plant - $7 billion. We are attracting regional HQs from Dupont, IBM, Toyota. We are building capabilities in emerging growth areas, supporting R&D, investing in higher education, trying to anticipate the next wave, but not just on one front. We are doing the right things - getting growth and investments and making the tax changes to put our economy on a sound footing, to enjoy economic growth beyond the short term.

    I fully agree with Mrs Yu-Foo that we must take heart, and we must not be discouraged. There is reason to be confident. With the economic restructuring package, we have made the first step, and we can look forward to facing the future with hope and confidence. [Applause.]
